Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Corinthian(?) black-figured pottery open vessel, possibly a column-krater; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of two animal friezes separated by dilute band; above, goat grazing to left (snout, one foreleg and three hooves remaining); rough pinwheel rosettes as filling ornament; below, swan (head remaining) to right and two confronting boars (legs missing from one and only tip of snout and ear remaining of second); incised dot and blob rosettes as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 123, pl. XXXVIII, no. 347.2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.201) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.6006 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
